Award.AbstractNarration:
Hypergeometric functions are power series (in one or several variables) whose coefficients satisfy a two-term recursion. Their very definition makes hypergeometric functions amenable to treatment by analytic and combinatorial methods. The study of their differential equations from a D-module theoretic point of view is the subject of this project. A breakthrough in the late 1980s due to Gelfand, Graev, Kapranov and Zelevinsky provided a new connection between hypergeometric functions (in several variables) and the theory of toric varieties, a subfield of algebraic geometry with a strong combinatorial flavor. This link has made available a variety of algebraic, homological and combinatorial tools to study hypergeometric differential equations and their solutions. The goal of this project is to advance the theory of hypergeometric functions and differential equations.


The solutions of hypergeometric differential equations comprise a rich and interesting class of functions. Familiar functions, such as the trigonometric functions, belong to this class. The importance of these functions lies in their usefulness, not only within mathematics, but in physics and engineering as well. The present research will provide advances in the theory of hypergeometric differential equations; its underlying philosophy is to view hypergeometric functions as bridges between different areas of mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Hypergeometric functions are of great use throughout Mathematics, and also in Science and Engineering. Among them are such familiar functions as the trigonometric and exponential functions. Furthermore, this class of functions also contains the solutions of polynomial equations in terms of the coefficients. Developing a theory that encompasses such seemingly disparate but uniformly important examples is very challenging. In the late 1980s, Gelfand, Graev, Kapranov and Zelevinsky introduced a new approach to the study of hypergeometric functions and differential equations. Among their many contributions, they greatly simplified the hypergeometric equations, which now are of two types: constant coefficient equations with two terms, and order one equations involving parameters. The study of polynomial equations with two terms is of great interest in its own right, as many physical phenomena can be modeled by such equations. This project focuses on developing the theory of multivariate hypergeometric differential equations, and the related study of polynomial equations with two terms.

Intellectual Merit:  This project has produced significant advances in the theory of multivariate hypergeometric functions and differential equations, including the first structural results on singularities of hypergeometric systems of Horn type, as well as a new understanding of the parametric behavior of hypergeometric functions. New computational and theoretical tools were also developed for the study of polynomial equations with two terms.

Broader Impacts: The PI has closely mentored her two graduate students (one of whom received her PhD during this grant period). The PI has served as mentored to another graduate student collaborator, and also as postdoctoral mentor for two postdocs.
